content.webTitle: Jay Weatherill asked to conduct 'warts-and-all' review of Labor's election loss

fields.headline: Jay Weatherill asked to conduct 'warts-and-all' review of Labor's election loss
fields.bodyText: Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill and retired Queensland MP Craig Emerson are expected to review Labor’s failed election campaign, as the party prepares for a confronting postmortem examination of its defeat. As MPs regroup under new leader Anthony Albanese following the 18 May election, the Labor executive has begun turning its mind to how it reviews the campaign that saw the party lose against public and polling expectations. Weatherill, a left-aligned member of the party who served as the South Australian premier from 2011 to 2018, has been named as the most likely figure to lead the “warts-and-all” review of Bill Shorten’s campaign. The party’s Right faction has proposed that Emerson also have a key role in the evaluation of what went wrong in the party’s campaign, with the former MP for Rankin to examine Labor’s poor showing in Queensland. The ALP federal executive, which now has a majority of left-aligned members, with Albanese having the casting vote, will meet in Canberra next month to finalise the parameters of the review. Former Western Australian MP Gary Gray was also asked to be involved, but declined the offer. Weatherill confirmed he had been approached, and was prepared to conduct the inquiry. “I’m happy to serve the party in any way that they think is appropriate but it is entirely a matter for the Labor party and it’s new leadership,” Weatherill told Guardian Australia. Albanese, who convened the first meeting of shadow cabinet in Brisbane on Tuesday, has said the party will reset its policy agenda following the election loss after hearing the “verdict of the people”. “Well, those of us who were in positions in the Labor party have to accept the outcome and have to accept that we made some strategic errors,” Albanese said. “We listened to the verdict of the people. The people always get it right. There’s no point complaining about what happened on the field. When you look at the scoreboard at the end of the day, we were defeated by about 77-68.” Shorten, whose unpopularity has been raised as a key reason for the party’s defeat, has blamed “vested interests” for the loss, suggesting Clive Palmer and the Murdoch press “got what they want” with the election result. MPs, however, have said the party’s controversial tax reform measures, particularly the winding back of franking credits, damaged the party’s chances. In the aftermath of the campaign, WA Labor premier Mark McGowan criticised the federal campaign for being too ambitious. “They planted a huge target on themselves, their policies were way too grandiose, way too many, they didn’t have a core theme to them,” McGowan said. “Because they had so much to talk about, people couldn’t latch on to a single thing, and then they allowed themselves to become the issue. “In an election campaign when you’re fighting against the government, the government should be the issue, not the opposition.
